block.p: Tens of Thousands Rally Against Troop Increase Tens of thousands of protesters converged on the National Mall in Washington to oppose President Bush's plan to send more troops to Iraq. Organizers were hoping it would be one of the largest shows of antiwar sentiment in the nation's capital since the war began.
PAGE 21
Virulent TB Threatens Africa Experts say a drug-resistant form of tuberculosis found across South Africa may spread to neighboring countries and pose a risk to millions unless urgent action is taken.
PAGE 6
Test for U.S.-Israel Arms Pact Israel may have violated agreements with the United States when it used American-supplied cluster bombs last year, officials say.
PAGE 3
Rehabilitating Robert Moses With New York poised for a building boom, the legacy of Robert Moses is getting a fresh, and maybe a more favorable, look.
ARTS & LEISURE

Hitting the Campaign Trail Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, starting her campaign roadshow in Iowa, portrayed herself as a fighter, and, in New Hampshire, Rudolph W. Giuliani was sounding more like a presidential candidate.
PAGE 16

Perilous, and Illegal, Trip to U.S. Begins in Southern Mexico Despite a crackdown on illegal immigration by the new president of Mexico, Central American migrants still flock across its southern border and hop the freight train in Arriaga for the journey to the United States.
PAGE 12

The Future of Microsoft Microsoft is feeling the heat of the Internet revolution, and deciding how to respond has fallen to its chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, profiled in one of several features that are new this week.
SUNDAY BUSINESS

Tens of Thousands Rally Against Troop Increase Tens of thousands of protesters converged on the National Mall in Washington to oppose President Bush's plan to send more troops to Iraq. Organizers were hoping it would be one of the largest shows of antiwar sentiment in the nation's capital since the war began.
